title.narrative: UEWCA - ICT for Girls Education and Womens Entrepreneurship
UEWCA - ICT för flickors utbildning och kvinnligt entreprenörsskap

description.narrative: The overall objective of the intervention is to empower marginalized women and girls to decide on socioeconomic issues equally as their counterparts and lead better living conditions by creating access and skills to use Information and Information Technology.

Stödet till UEWCA utgår i form av projektstöd. Sida gjorde en utlysning för insatser i enlighet med "Strategi för kapacitetsutveckling och samverkan 2011 – 2013". Utlysningen fick 300 förslag varav Sida valde att gå vidare med fem. Ett av dessa förslag kom från UWECA.
Det övergripande målet med projektet är att öka flickors tillgång till Informations och kommunikationsverktyg (ICT) i skolan samt att ge kvinnor tillgång till ICT som ett sätt att utveckla entreprenöriella tjänster.
Den totala kostnaden för insatsen är 975 695 USD, varav Sida har åtagit sig att disponera högst 6 206 000 SEK.

This intervention will establish internet centers for rural girls and marginalized women to create access to information on academic, business, economic and social issues. The targeted girls are secondary school students. The targeted women are marginalized women organized into Self-Help Groups, Business Cooperatives and Saving and Saving and Credit Organizations.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: UEWCA and its partner organisations have established 20 internet centres in different areas of the country. 10 centres targeted girs students and have been set up in secondary and preparatory schools in rural areas. Computer trainings have been provided to more than 500 teachers and 600 high school girl students/peer educators, and successively scaled up through peer education to more than 10 000 students. 10 centres target female entrepreneurs. Computer trainings have been provided to 220 entrepreneur women/ peer educators and scaled up though peer to peer education to more than 1700 female entrepreneurs.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
